metadata.title: Influence of blood pressure on pneumonia risk: 1 Epidemiological association and Mendelian randomisation in the UK Biobank 2 3 4

abstract.text: word count: 258 31 Main text word count: 3,878 32 Main display item count: 4 33 Reference count: 52 34 35 Abstract:
Objectives -To determine whether elevated blood pressure influences risk for respiratory 3 infection.
Design -Prospective, population-based epidemiological and Mendelian randomisation studies.
Participants -377,143 self-identified British descent (54% women; median age 58 years)

body_text.text: Hypertension is a highly prevalent, modifiable risk factor for cardiovascular disease and 3 mortality 1 . Epidemiologic analyses have correlated hypertension with pneumonia risk in small 4 studies 2 3 . Whether this represents a direct consequence of hypertension or influence of co-5 morbid risk factors such as age, diabetes mellitus, air pollution, or smoking is unclear.

Hypertension has emerged as one of the most well-recognized risk factors for developing novel 8 coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) from SARS-CoV-2 infection [4] [5] [6] [7] . In particular, patients with 9 COVID-19 who develop acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) are particularly enriched 10 for hypertension 7 . Angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) is an endogenous regulator of blood 11 pressure that is highly expressed in the lung and has been linked to risk for acute respiratory 12 distress syndrome (ARDS) 8 9 . ACE2, a homolog and endogenous counter-regulator of ACE, is 13 expressed in a subset of type II alveolar cells and is an important facilitator of cell entry by 14 SARS-CoV-2 [8] [9] [10] . ACE2 has also been implicated in lung injury related to other respiratory 15 viruses and bacterial pathogens [11] [12] [13] . While professional societies have encouraged patients to 16 remain on ACE inhibitors during the present pandemic, recommendations were largely made in 17 the absence of robust human data.

Although epidemiologic analyses support a plausible causal relationship between blood 20 pressure regulation and respiratory infection risk, confounding from comorbid conditions limit 21 such inference. Importantly, comorbid factors such as advanced age, diabetes mellitus, and 22 cardiovascular disease have also been described as independent risk factors for pneumonia 23 previously as well as for COVID-19. Mendelian randomisation is a statistical approach using 24 genetic proxies for an exposure as opposed to the exposure itself to mitigate risks for 25 confounding facilitating more robust causal inference 14 . Blood pressure is a highly heritable trait 26 . body_text.text: Thus, withdrawal of ACEi and challenges of blood pressure management while promoting 12 physical distancing, may not only have untoward cardiovascular consequences but may 13 inadvertently increase pneumonia risk.

Strengths and limitations 16 17 This study has several strengths, including the analysis of a large, genotyped population-based 18 cohort with high fidelity phenotyping, including with subclinical respiratory phenotypes.

Furthermore, diverse phenotyping facilitates extensive individual-level covariate adjustment in 20 the models and sensitivity analyses to assess for pleiotropy. body_text.text: Our study provides evidence that hypertension directly influences the risk of pneumonia.
Vigilance for blood pressure monitoring and management may reduce risk for pneumonia,
including potentially for the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

FIGREF31.text: Our observation is consistent with prior unadjusted estimates in retrospective 8 analyses 2 28 . Although significantly associated, the effect of hypertension adjusted for important 9 confounders on future risk for pneumonia is more moderate, as anticipated. Furthermore, our 10 genetic analyses are consistent with a causal relationship between blood pressure and 11 pneumonia. Hypertension has been proposed to promote key factors which may predispose to 12 infection via several potential mechanisms. (1) Hypertensive stimuli promote dysregulation of 13 the adaptive immune response. Chronic angiotensin II infusions in mice increase markers of T 14 lymphocyte activation and perivascular adipose infiltration 29 . Additional murine studies have 15 indicated that monocytes and neutrophils may be key factors in angiotensin II-mediated 16 hypertension and resultant vascular dysfunction 30 31 . A recent Mendelian randomisation study 17 supported a causal relationship between blood pressure and subsequent alteration in 18 neutrophil, monocyte, and eosinophil indices 32 . (2) Endothelial dysfunction as a consequence of 19 hypertension may promote infection. Dysregulation of nitric oxide release and signalling in 20 murine models of pulmonary inflammation leads to exacerbated lung injury 33 . Furthermore, 21 superoxides generated from endothelial NADPH oxidase may play a role in exacerbating22influenza-associated lung injury in experimental models34 .

FIGREF32.text: in addition immunologic and vascular effects, blood pressure elevations may result in 25 pulmonary function alterations predisposing to the development of pneumonia. pulmonary function tests, reduced lung function, and increased pulmonary 4 obstruction 35-37 . Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a well-established risk factor 5 for pneumonia, and is co-morbid with several cardiovascular diseases and risk factors including 6 hypertension 38 . Our study extends these observations to show that increased blood pressure 7 may causally lead to increased pulmonary obstruction representing a putative mechanism 8 toward heightened pneumonia risk.
